defs.docs: Tools for working with tasks.

attributes.value: / Tools for working with tasks.

warn(missing_docs, missing_debug_implementations, rust_2018_idioms,
       unreachable_pub)

defs.name: Spawn
defs.docs:
The `Spawn` trait allows for pushing futures onto an executor that will
 run them to completion.

attributes.value: / The `Spawn` trait allows for pushing futures onto an executor that will
/ run them to completion.

defs.name: spawn_obj
defs.value: pub fn spawn_obj(&Self, FutureObj) -> Result<(), SpawnError>
defs.docs: Spawns a future that will be run to completion.

attributes.value: / Spawns a future that will be run to completion.
/ # Errors
/ The executor may be unable to spawn tasks. Spawn errors should
/ represent relatively rare scenarios, such as the executor
/ having been shut down so that it is no longer able to accept
/ tasks.

defs.name: status
defs.docs: Determines whether the executor is able to spawn new tasks.

attributes.value: / Determines whether the executor is able to spawn new tasks.
/ This method will return `Ok` when the executor is *likely*
/ (but not guaranteed) to accept a subsequent spawn attempt.
/ Likewise, an `Err` return means that `spawn` is likely, but
/ not guaranteed, to yield an error.
inline

defs.name: LocalSpawn
defs.docs:
The `LocalSpawn` is similar to [`Spawn`], but allows spawning futures
 that don't implement `Send`.

attributes.value: / The `LocalSpawn` is similar to [`Spawn`], but allows spawning futures
/ that don't implement `Send`.

defs.name: spawn_local_obj
defs.value: pub fn spawn_local_obj(&Self, LocalFutureObj) -> Result<(), SpawnError>
defs.docs: Spawns a future that will be run to completion.

attributes.value: / Spawns a future that will be run to completion.
/ # Errors
/ The executor may be unable to spawn tasks. Spawn errors should
/ represent relatively rare scenarios, such as the executor
/ having been shut down so that it is no longer able to accept
/ tasks.

defs.name: status_local
defs.docs: Determines whether the executor is able to spawn new tasks.

attributes.value: / Determines whether the executor is able to spawn new tasks.
/ This method will return `Ok` when the executor is *likely*
/ (but not guaranteed) to accept a subsequent spawn attempt.
/ Likewise, an `Err` return means that `spawn` is likely, but
/ not guaranteed, to yield an error.
inline

defs.name: SpawnError
defs.docs: An error that occurred during spawning.

attributes.value: / An error that occurred during spawning.

defs.name: shutdown
defs.docs: Spawning failed because the executor has been shut down.

attributes.value: / Spawning failed because the executor has been shut down.

defs.name: is_shutdown
defs.docs: Check whether spawning failed to the executor being shut down.

attributes.value: / Check whether spawning failed to the executor being shut down.

defs.name: ArcWake
defs.docs: A way of waking up a specific task.

attributes.value: / A way of waking up a specific task.
/ By implementing this trait, types that are expected to be wrapped in an `Arc`
/ can be converted into [`Waker`] objects.
/ Those Wakers can be used to signal executors that a task it owns
/ is ready to be `poll`ed again.
/ Currently, there are two ways to convert `ArcWake` into [`Waker`]:
/ * [`waker`](super::waker()) converts `Arc<impl ArcWake>` into [`Waker`].
/ * [`waker_ref`](super::waker_ref()) converts `&Arc<impl ArcWake>` into [`WakerRef`] that
/   provides access to a [`&Waker`][`Waker`].
/ [`Waker`]: std::task::Waker
/ [`WakerRef`]: super::WakerRef

defs.name: wake
defs.docs:
Indicates that the associated task is ready to make progress and should
 be `poll`ed.

attributes.value: / Indicates that the associated task is ready to make progress and should
/ be `poll`ed.
/ This function can be called from an arbitrary thread, including threads which
/ did not create the `ArcWake` based [`Waker`].
/ Executors generally maintain a queue of "ready" tasks; `wake` should place
/ the associated task onto this queue.
/ [`Waker`]: std::task::Waker

defs.name: wake_by_ref
defs.docs:
Indicates that the associated task is ready to make progress and should
 be `poll`ed.

attributes.value: / Indicates that the associated task is ready to make progress and should
/ be `poll`ed.
/ This function can be called from an arbitrary thread, including threads which
/ did not create the `ArcWake` based [`Waker`].
/ Executors generally maintain a queue of "ready" tasks; `wake_by_ref` should place
/ the associated task onto this queue.
/ This function is similar to [`wake`](ArcWake::wake), but must not consume the provided data
/ pointer.
/ [`Waker`]: std::task::Waker

defs.name: waker
defs.value: pub fn waker<W>(Arc<W>) -> Waker where W: ArcWake + 'static
defs.docs: Creates a [`Waker`] from an `Arc<impl ArcWake>`.

attributes.value: / Creates a [`Waker`] from an `Arc<impl ArcWake>`.
/ The returned [`Waker`] will call
/ [`ArcWake.wake()`](ArcWake::wake) if awoken.

defs.name: WakerRef
defs.docs: A [`Waker`] that is only valid for a given lifetime.

attributes.value: / A [`Waker`] that is only valid for a given lifetime.
/ Note: this type implements [`Deref<Target = Waker>`](std::ops::Deref),
/ so it can be used to get a `&Waker`.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create a new [`WakerRef`] from a [`Waker`] reference.

attributes.value: / Create a new [`WakerRef`] from a [`Waker`] reference.

defs.name: new_unowned
defs.docs: Create a new [`WakerRef`] from a [`Waker`] that must not be dropped.

attributes.value: / Create a new [`WakerRef`] from a [`Waker`] that must not be dropped.
/ Note: this if for rare cases where the caller created a [`Waker`] in
/ an unsafe way (that will be valid only for a lifetime to be determined
/ by the caller), and the [`Waker`] doesn't need to or must not be
/ destroyed.

defs.name: waker_ref
defs.value: pub fn waker_ref<W>(&Arc<W>) -> WakerRef where W: ArcWake
defs.docs: Creates a reference to a [`Waker`] from a reference to `Arc<impl ArcWake>`.

attributes.value: / Creates a reference to a [`Waker`] from a reference to `Arc<impl ArcWake>`.
/ The resulting [`Waker`] will call
/ [`ArcWake.wake()`](ArcWake::wake) if awoken.
inline

defs.name: LocalFutureObj
defs.docs:
A custom trait object for polling futures, roughly akin to
 `Box<dyn Future<Output = T> + 'a>`.

attributes.value: / A custom trait object for polling futures, roughly akin to
/ `Box<dyn Future<Output = T> + 'a>`.
/ This custom trait object was introduced as currently it is not possible to
/ take `dyn Trait` by value and `Box<dyn Trait>` is not available in no_std
/ contexts.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create a `LocalFutureObj` from a custom trait object representation.

attributes.value: / Create a `LocalFutureObj` from a custom trait object representation.
inline

defs.name: into_future_obj
defs.docs: Converts the `LocalFutureObj` into a `FutureObj`.

attributes.value: / Converts the `LocalFutureObj` into a `FutureObj`.
/ # Safety
/ To make this operation safe one has to ensure that the `UnsafeFutureObj`
/ instance from which this `LocalFutureObj` was created actually
/ implements `Send`.
inline

defs.name: FutureObj
defs.docs:
A custom trait object for polling futures, roughly akin to
 `Box<dyn Future<Output = T> + Send + 'a>`.

attributes.value: / A custom trait object for polling futures, roughly akin to
/ `Box<dyn Future<Output = T> + Send + 'a>`.
/ This custom trait object was introduced as currently it is not possible to
/ take `dyn Trait` by value and `Box<dyn Trait>` is not available in no_std
/ contexts.
/ You should generally not need to use this type outside of `no_std` or when
/ implementing `Spawn`, consider using `BoxFuture` instead.

defs.name: new
defs.value: pub fn new<F: UnsafeFutureObj + Send>(F) -> Self
defs.docs: Create a `FutureObj` from a custom trait object representation.

attributes.value: / Create a `FutureObj` from a custom trait object representation.
inline

defs.name: UnsafeFutureObj
defs.docs:
A custom implementation of a future trait object for `FutureObj`, providing
 a vtable with drop support.

attributes.value: / A custom implementation of a future trait object for `FutureObj`, providing
/ a vtable with drop support.
/ This custom representation is typically used only in `no_std` contexts,
/ where the default `Box`-based implementation is not available.
/ # Safety
/ See the safety notes on individual methods for what guarantees an
/ implementor must provide.

defs.name: into_raw
defs.docs: Convert an owned instance into a (conceptually owned) fat pointer.

attributes.value: / Convert an owned instance into a (conceptually owned) fat pointer.
/ # Safety
/ ## Implementor
/ The trait implementor must guarantee that it is safe to convert the
/ provided `*mut (dyn Future<Output = T> + 'a)` into a `Pin<&mut (dyn
/ Future<Output = T> + 'a)>` and call methods on it, non-reentrantly,
/ until `UnsafeFutureObj::drop` is called with it.

defs.name: drop
defs.value: pub unsafe fn drop(*mut Future<Output = T> + 'a)
defs.docs: Drops the future represented by the given fat pointer.

attributes.value: / Drops the future represented by the given fat pointer.
/ # Safety
/ ## Implementor
/ The trait implementor must guarantee that it is safe to call this
/ function once per `into_raw` invocation.
/ ## Caller
/ The caller must ensure:
/  * the pointer passed was obtained from an `into_raw` invocation from
/    this same trait object
/  * the pointer is not currently in use as a `Pin<&mut (dyn Future<Output
/  * the pointer must not be used again after this function is called

defs.name: noop_waker
defs.docs:
Create a new [`Waker`] which does
 nothing when `wake()` is called on it.

attributes.value: / Create a new [`Waker`] which does
/ nothing when `wake()` is called on it.
/ # Examples
/ use futures::task::noop_waker;
/ let waker = noop_waker();
/ waker.wake();
inline

defs.name: noop_waker_ref
defs.docs:
Get a static reference to a [`Waker`] which
 does nothing when `wake()` is called on it.

attributes.value: / Get a static reference to a [`Waker`] which
/ does nothing when `wake()` is called on it.
/ # Examples
/ use futures::task::noop_waker_ref;
/ let waker = noop_waker_ref();
/ waker.wake_by_ref();
inline
